issue.title: Make training code more generic to make it possible to train on other kinds of objects (e.g. commits)

repository.name: bugbug
repository.description: Platform for Machine Learning projects on Software Engineering

issue.body: This also adds a model to predict if a commit will be backed out (not greatly performing of course, as it is quite hard to predict).

body: @marco-c How is the script/trainer.py supposed to run? (I see that we can't run it from the command line directly.)

You can run it like this: `python3 -c 'from scripts import trainer; trainer.main()'`.

This issue is a bit problematic, as we need to make a few decisions before moving stuff, so let's not do it yet.
We can now do this, so I've added back the 'good-first-bug' label.
You can also launch it with `bugbug-train`
@asmaknikar you can work on any issue which is unassigned and has no open PR linked to it (read CONTRIBUTING.md).
Hi @marco-c , So I was kind of interesting to take this issue, Actually I have one doubt, that do we have to run this functionality by some Bash script or by direct script/trainer.py ?

We need to split the run.py functionality into multiple scripts under script/.
(Part of) The train functionality is already in trainer.py.

Seems like args.classify and args.generate_sheet could be split into scripts called bug_classifier.py and generate_sheet.py (or some other names along those lines). However, both of these require a trained model. Do you want these scripts to call the trainer.py script to train the models if the file can't be loaded? Or should the user be informed that the model should be trained beforehand by running trainer.py?

> Or should the user be informed that the model should be trained beforehand by running trainer.py?

This one!

I think this will be easier to review if it's broken into multiple PRs. I plan to divide this into:

- [x] generate_sheet.py

- [x] bug_classifier.py

- [x] add extra functionality to trainer.py

- [x] remove run.py and update readme

I can do it in one PR if you'd prefer though.
Yeah, breaking into multiple PRs is the best option!

issue.title: Separate generate_sheet from run.py

repository.name: bugbug
repository.description: Platform for Machine Learning projects on Software Engineering

issue.body:
Addresses #339
I moved the code to load the model and everything under `if args.generate_sheet:` from run.py into this script.
I was able to run the command with 
`python3 -c 'from scripts import generate_sheet; generate_sheet.main()' model token`.

Here's an example of the csv that was generated.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23666591/62259361-0d5ebb80-b3dc-11e9-82aa-a8a9b27509f4.png)

repository.name: bugbug
repository.description: Platform for Machine Learning projects on Software Engineering

issue.title: Add arguments to trainer script

repository.name: bugbug
repository.description: Platform for Machine Learning projects on Software Engineering

issue.body:
Addresses #339 
In the test, the duplicate model took ~5 min to train while the defect model took ~13, so I used the one that took a shorter time.
